utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, you don't. But one day, perhaps. What about the fact that it was the lowest rated Oscars in the history of the world.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: There has been a bit of a trend of that. That's also true with other big awards shows and also big sporting events. Except like when you have a championship. But I think it's mostly because there's so many other choices.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: So last night, for example, I -- we decided to watch the Edward R. Israel Esquire movie, the one with Denzel Washington, instead of watching the Oscars. But during the movie, Peter kept telling me who was winning for best hair because he got it on his phone. And so, I think, there're so many ways you can get information out. The other thing is, one of the reasons that we hadn't seen all the movies until the last couple weeks is because we don't typically go to the theater anymore. You wait until you can watch it at home. And then, you know how much it cost us last night? It was something like $4.99 to rent that movie.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: We watched it and we're in the comfort of our own home. And so I just think that the technology is changing the way we can have access to it. It's like going to the old dollar theater. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb18', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb18', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: No, they weren't dirty.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, I mean, the inside were dirty.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: I used to work at the movies. They were very dirty. That's why they keep the lights off. Plus, you want to see the movie. The other thing to keep in mind, I think 50 percent of the people did not watch because they thought it's almost giving into the other side. I'm telling you, when Jimmy Kimmel hosted this, when Hollywood does what they did, 50 percent of the country said if I tune in I'm giving up on President Trump or President Bush or Republicans, and I will not give those Democrats ratings.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You know what I find interesting, the goody bag, Kimberly, had over $100,000 in trips and electronics and do that, and it proves that point. The more that you get in life, the more you get in life. Like, these people do not need free things. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb19', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb19', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yeah. Billionaires don't pay for anything. But then, you know, everybody likes a little swag bag. And believe me, they're the first to grab them, OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah, yeah, they are. They'll trample over a poor family to get that trip.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Oh, and people try to take two and then not go through the line and give it to their driver and go back through again. That was the other Meryl Streep.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Put me in this one. It's bad.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That was Glenn Close.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: You don't want to be too negative on the Oscars. I'll give you some positives. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb20', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb20', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: I liked the whole thing with the jet ski.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Brilliant. The jet ski was brilliant. The idea you give the shortest speech, you win a jet ski and a trip to Lake Havasu.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: Some casting director got it for 31 seconds.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That was hilarious.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Who wants to go to Lake Havasu? Kidding. I know my sister goes to Lake Havasu.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Wow. I guess we know where your bread is buttered. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb21', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb21', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: No, I know Lake Havasu.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: By the way, you know what -- you guys haven't mentioned?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I thought -- and this picks up on what you were talking about, the entertainment factor that people want to be entertained.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Often times, the best movies are not blockbuster hits is what I'm trying to say, and none of these are. They're good movies. But the ones that are blockbuster hits, right now, the ones -- guess what, you have women like Wonder Woman, right, a woman, and then you have.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: Black Panther.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Black Panther, and even Get Out, a horror film with a black lead actor. I think there's something different given #metoo going on in Hollywood. So maybe they are changing, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I thought -- my favorite moment in the Oscars was Eva Marie Saint. She's 93. She's more articulate in coaching than anybody out there. And I think what's missing, it's like -- I liked to watch -- when I was a kid I like to watch the Oscars to see Charlton Heston and Jimmy Stewart. They come out and they're not their characters. They're themselves. But in this case, when you see movie stars now, they are -- they conform to a certain character about saying the right things, the right moral posture. That didn't exist in the '70s. They were just out there getting drunk.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: But you know what, that's -- I can't follow you. That's all right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I know.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: I was going to follow you but I can't pretend to. I will say this, why can't the biggest box office smash hit be lauded? Why can't they get awards?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You mean Trump, the movie?

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Trump is a bigger movie than all of them.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: Like Black Panther is not get any awards. It's eligible for next year, right? It's not going to get any awards.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I bet it does.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It will get best picture nod, no question.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, I don't think so.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You don't think so?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: It could be. But I don't think.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's the right movie.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: X-men? How many awards did X-men win?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: None.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: Because they're the most successful movies don't get awarded. As if they're saying, I know what you like but I know better.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: My favorite Oscars story. Do we have a picture of Emma Watson? A lovely actress. I think, I hope that this is actually a temporary tattoo. It probably is. But it says times up, a salute to the movement. But there's no apostrophe. I think she should sue.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I wonder -- think it's a temporary tattoo.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: Henna?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: A misspelled temporary tattoo. How lame.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: A damning assessment by Dana Perino. She's an expert on temporary henna tattoos, by the way.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You know if you're going to get a tattoo, make it temporary. I mean, really.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: What about the people disinvite? Casey Affleck can't go. James Franco can't go.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Do you have time when you have to wrap on Fox & Friends?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Not at all.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: Usually people are screaming at me.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: New calls for a second special counsel. That's next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: The DOJ has come under some scrutiny for how it obtained a FISA court warrant on a former member of the Trump campaign. Support is now growing among Republicans in congress for a second special counsel:

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I expect the inspector general to issue a fact-centric fair report. I don't think the inspector general, himself, can answer all of our questions. Some of these witnesses have already left the department, which means the inspector general does not have jurisdiction. And there are other agencies like the state department where Michael Horowitz at DOJ has no jurisdiction whatsoever. So I think we're trending perhaps towards another special counsel, because of this unique fact pattern and the fact that there are witnesses outside the reach of the inspector general.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: So Kimberly, this is a shift. For a long time, Republicans have been saying they believe that Michael Horowitz, the inspector general, could handle all of this. And there are mechanisms by which the inspector general, if he needed to, get a previous DOJ employee to talk to him. If they're not willing to, that he could use a U.S. attorney to go -- but I think what the Republicans are trying to do here is to try to stop the partisanship of this investigation and try to see if they should go to a second special counsel. The question for you is should they be careful what they wish for on that?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Well, certainly, right? I mean, it's kind of a double edge sword. When you think about it, you know, you say OK. Well, basically it sounds like a good idea. And you are seeing more of a measure of support from Republicans to do that. You saw a lot of that across the airwaves today, former tea party guy, Jordan saying it as well. But perhaps it would be warranted or this is an important situation. But yes, it is a shift in Republican paradigm to even say let's go to a special counsel. When you think about the amount of work and the things they have to do to get through it and try to do something expeditiously in the interest of efficiency, as well in getting away from partisan politics. It sounds like a good idea but it could also lead to a whole other road and take forever and give more time to go through things. One of the criticisms of Mueller is -- OK, how about focusing on what you originally were looking at in the original charges, the original focus and scope of the investigation, then it tends to always broaden out. Tentacles.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Right. And then, Juan, I guess another problem could be that it depends on who you get as a special counsel, because then, if it's not -- if that person is not to President Trump's liking or the Democrats' liking, then maybe there still won't be any trust at the end of this. But there's two things, as I understand it, this would be for, supposedly, possible FISA (INAUDIBLE). But I think that a lot of people in the Trump world think this would be for everything including Hillary Clinton's emails.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, exactly. And in fact, a lot of this really stems from one so-called Republican, Donald Trump, because he's the one that's been going after the inspector general, Michael Horowitz, and saying, hey, that's an Obama guy. Why aren't you, Mr. Magoo, speaking to his attorney general in the most disrespectful way possible? Why aren't you getting Justice Department lawyers to work on this case instead of the inspector general? And then he says go after Hillary Clinton, but that's not what this is about. It's supposed to be about questions regarding FISA and, again, his own Justice Department. His own FBI says this is not -- this is reckless, this is dangerous, don't do it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, Brian, one possible thing is the inspector general, the Justice Department is having to investigate the Justice Department. And having worked there, I know that can't be done, but the possibility of having a second special counsel would then perhaps give this a veneer of credibility that the investigation right now doesn't have because of what's happened to the politicization of the intel committee.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: Couple of things. The casual way of which Juan Williams said Mr. Magoo in the conversation, just go to show you.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: He didn't say it casually.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: I know. But just the way he says Mr. Magoo, of course, we know Jeff Sessions. I am as curious as anybody what Loretta Lynch did behind closed doors. I'm very curious what happened with James Comey. I am very curious what's going on with this FISA court. I do not -- as much as frustrated as everybody is, mostly Republicans are, but some Democrats, I don't want another special counsel. The country cannot go through this again. It makes everything fundamentally worse. It makes people go into their corners. We never get anything done. I echo what Condoleezza Rice said at the end of The View, when she looked over at Adam Schiff and she said I understand you have an important job but wrap it up. The country needs to get over this. If we go do this again and we start living 2015 and 2016, it will be bad for the country and it will not help the Republicans either.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, I mean, it could help the Republicans, I guess. Or maybe it would just be good to get justice.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I disagree with everything that Brian Kilmeade said.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: What is going on.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I believe that a second counsel -- special counsel is not enough. We need a third special counsel, and we need a fourth special counsel. It should never end. It should be special counsel roshambo, like I've said before. People are already in their corners. This is all team sports stuff. There's an ongoing mission going on right now. It's not to beat Trump, it's to stop Trump, because I think that the media and the Democrats have realized that they actually have to admit that President Trump is doing a much better job as president than they can admit or can actually fight. And it actually may end up -- has a lot more in common with the American public's perceptions than them. So what they have to do is stop him, not beat him. This is what they're doing.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Second special counsel would be, supposedly, to help President Trump.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah. You know what, I've tuned out. Like a said, special counsel.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: He's not better as they thought. He just doesn't go down with a punch. They thought they'd hit him a couple of times and he would go down.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: Instead, it turns out he doesn't mind it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: That's what they say the chaos, he doesn't mind the chaos.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, he doesn't.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: We're going to talk about that because ahead, turmoil in the White House. The president's former chief of staff says don't be distracted by the talk. Next.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Chaos, turmoil, madness, no, not The Five. But all kinds of word are being thrown around to describe the Trump White House. Someone who once had a front seat to it all says ignore the talk. The president process may be different, but it's getting great results. Here's Reince Priebus.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: You can't look at the distractions. I think what the staff has to do is focus in on the results. And so, I think what the president does and he writes about it even in his own books, is he puts rivals around him intellectually. You have people like Wilbur Ross, who was going to be on your show, and Gary Cohn, and he puts those two guys in front of him and says, OK, fight out tariffs in front of me and they fight it out. The media covers the fight, but ultimately the decision is made. Look at the economy. Look at ISIS. Look at the courts. The decisions and the things that President Trump has done have put him on a great course. That process, while different, has gotten to good results. And that's what I think people need to do.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: OK. It's very curious to see Reince Priebus out, kind of doing these talking points on the Sunday show. So he's trying to direct the attention away from chaos, away from General Kelly, or staff changes, Cohn, McMaster, is there turmoil there to say, OK. Well, the process and make it about the president, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: So Reince hasn't really done a lot of press from about.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: . August until recently. I assume that maybe he got the time off that he needed. And that the White House is looking for allies and support and ask him if he would consider going out there and talking about things from his perspective because he was there. He has credibility from that point. I would say from the chaos standpoint, it's never as bad as it looks from the outside because 98 percent of people who worked at the White House have very specific jobs that they have to do. The government is clearly running well and on time, so that's isn't a concern. Maybe it's 95 percent at this White House because there is no doubt that we talk about the personnel issues at this White House all the time, and a lot of that is self-imposed. But the crowdsourcing of the policy debate, it is different. Like we are having a debate about tariffs this week out in the open and we're all participating. I have people on my show today participating and everyone is sending in input, so it's a different way to do policy time, and it just ends up being what it is. I would say also though that when the President was able to work more cooperatively with Paul Ryan and Mitch McConnell in the Congress and that started around August-September, that's when a lot of these things started really coming together for getting a lot of accomplishments done. Things turned the corner, so that now, when you have a week where it looks like there's chaos, at least they can point back and say, "Well, it might be chaos, but at least, you should like the results. Don't you like the economy? And so, Ryan says something to go out and talk about.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yes, it is. It's curious to see him kind of back out again, but it's highlighting the point that maybe things weren't going so well when he was there? Is it going better when Kelly is here, it's kind of -- it seems like he is helping to try to push some of the press away from General Kelly -- chaos -- Cohn, McMaster -- all of that, which I think is very specific that this isn't happening by accident, but as to the moral piece too, it's you know, good advice for the internal staff not to get distracted. If morale is super low, you do run the risk of losing good people.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: You do and a couple of things, I am not sure I believe a lot of it. Some of it is flat-out contradictory. According to four sources inside the White House, John Kelly has been used as a confidant by the President to get rid of Jared and his daughter. Really? I am having the marine four-star general run interference to tell Ivanka, "I need you to go home and work on shoes and dresses."

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: You really believe that?

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: No, I don't, but that's part of the headlines and part of the narratives. Some of this stuff is contradictory and does not make sense.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Okay.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: So, I don't buy that it is as chaotic as it is. Also, you have a guy in there who doesn't mind having unrest where you and I perhaps might have stomach churning moments, he is fine with it. Did you see him Friday at that -- when he was talking about tariffs? Didn't have a care in the world. You see and hear about him Saturday at the Gridiron, he had a great time, and the fund-raiser Friday night, the guy is not getting worked up.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, meaning President Trump?

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yes. Well, he seems to be able to thrive or survive well in chaos or stability. Right? I mean, that's kind of his nature. He is used to it. Juan, what do you think?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, I just don't understand. It seems to me total chaos. I mean, and I would just say look at the guns debate last week where one minute it looks like "Oh, he is taking on the NRA." Then the NRA comes back and says, "No, he agrees with us." No resolution. How about the trade debate? "Oh, one minute it says, yes, we are going to impose tariffs," And guess what? The stock market goes bananas, then he says, "You know, I am not so sure, but then yes, we are going to use it as a leverage point in terms of what's going on with Canada, our friend, and Mexico, our friend, in terms of the NAFTA debate." It's like, wait a second, White Houses -- Dana could speak to this -- typically are hierarchical and stick to message, so the message is clear to the public for political advantage. Here there is no -- it is like, you are a Republican? Like what side are the Republicans at? Today, Paul Ryan, the Speaker of the House, says, "I am not with Trump on trade." How is that helpful? What is the strategy? What is the strategy besides.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: . attacking your own Attorney General as Mr. Magoo, Brian?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Okay, well, who should be managing that, Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I am busy.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Captain Chaos?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Look, number one the -- we know why there is chaos. It's because we can see it, and I have said this before. This is the most transparent entity since Brian Stelter's hair. You can go see everything going inside of the White House, so that makes it look like there is more chaos. What I find interesting is how the media views Donald Trump as this incredibly divisive character when he has the most amorphous politics you could ever imagine. He is all over the place on immigration, guns, and trade. Guns, as you point out. Trade, as you point out, and even with immigration. He's going to let 1.7 million people in. It's because he's a populist and non-ideologue, which confuses people like us who play team sport politics, who believe that there is a right and left and set ideologies. He has more in common, and this may be bad, but it may be good, but he may have more in common with the average apolitical citizen who, when they hear an idea, they like that idea, but they also like that idea and both ideas might contradict each other. But he listens to both of them. To him and to the average, apolitical citizen, politics is a buffet and you walk in to that buffet and you can like this or here and you can like this over here, you don't see them as two separate teams. You say like, " I want the guns out of the hands of the crazy people. I want my guns." So, Trump goes, "You are both right." Because that is populism. So, it is what's popular and it changes because.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But it strikes me as like almost an autocrat.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yes, that (inaudible) -- like this, an autocrat. Ahead, President Trump breaking bread with the press this weekend and he actually had a great time, like Brian said, Gridiron dinner highlights when "The Five" returns.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: President Trump put his feud with the media on ice this weekend and guess what? He said he's never had so much fun. Can you believe it? Mr. Trump was actually self-deprecating.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: There we go -- at the annual Gridiron dinner in a roomful of journalists. Too bad it wasn't televised. But we've got you some quotes. He joked about the turnover at the White House, the impeachment calls, and more. He began with a clever apology for being a little late because his son-in-law, Jared -- and here I am just about quoting, "Could not get through security." Jared was there along with the first daughter, Ivanka. He also poked fun at his embattled Attorney General, Jeff Sessions saying, "Here with us tonight, I offered him a ride over, and he recused himself." The President even surprisingly had nice words for the press, and this is an accurate quote, folks, "I do have a lot of respect for a lot of people in this room. I want to think that press for all you do to support and sustain our democracy. I mean that." So, Dana, he hasn't accepted the White House correspondents' dinner.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That's okay.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: . this is the first time that he's done business with the press on a social level.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I heard his going.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, I haven't heard of it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I have no idea. I haven't been since 2008 and I don't plan to go again to the White House correspondents' dinner, but I love the Gridiron dinner. I think it's the best one, and one of the reasons it's the best is because it's not on camera. It is not televised. It has been going on for 160 years or something like that. It's at the Long Hill Club. It's one of the best nights in DC. I love the satire of it and I think that we all benefit from a night where the press and the President can hobnob behind the scenes, say whatever they want. Their motto is "The Gridiron singes, but it never burns." And I am a big fan of that night, but I don't care if he goes to the correspondents' dinner. Sorry, guys, I just don't, but I'm sorry.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Kimberly?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: I like it. I like the Gridiron. I thought that was a good show. The president is in good humor. I think it was a nice juxtaposition to a lot of the press out there, the chaos and this matter of what's going on, you know, here domestically, also you know, internationally. So, to see him in kind of good humor, making that kind of like inroads with the media, I thought that was good. You know, it just shows his flexibility and his versatility. And then, he's very good at these events, and I don't know, I am hearing he is going to do the White House correspondents' dinner. I mean, I'd like to go.

utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: I love the guy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Let me finish your point.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: OK, sir.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That your point is right. That given what they had to deal with in terms of the #metoo movement, the fact that -- I'm trying to think. Kobe Bryant.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: . who had been accused.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Very controversial.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Very controversial. And then, the guy I have been pushing, Gary Oldman, it turns out that he had -- some say that he was hitting her in the head with a phone or something, and this all comes rushing back. So it's almost like -- guess what, they're living in a glass house.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They are. Dana, you don't live in a glass house.

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, you don't. But one day, perhaps. What about the fact that it was the lowest rated Oscars in the history of the world.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: There has been a bit of a trend of that. That's also true with other big awards shows and also big sporting events. Except like when you have a championship. But I think it's mostly because there's so many other choices.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So last night, for example, I -- we decided to watch the Edward R. Israel Esquire movie, the one with Denzel Washington, instead of watching the Oscars. But during the movie, Peter kept telling me who was winning for best hair because he got it on his phone. And so, I think, there're so many ways you can get information out. The other thing is, one of the reasons that we hadn't seen all the movies until the last couple weeks is because we don't typically go to the theater anymore. You wait until you can watch it at home. And then, you know how much it cost us last night? It was something like $4.99 to rent that movie.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: We watched it and we're in the comfort of our own home. And so I just think that the technology is changing the way we can have access to it. It's like going to the old dollar theater.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: We have those.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Those were dirty.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, they weren't dirty.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, I mean, the inside were dirty.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: I used to work at the movies. They were very dirty. That's why they keep the lights off. Plus, you want to see the movie. The other thing to keep in mind, I think 50 percent of the people did not watch because they thought it's almost giving into the other side. I'm telling you, when Jimmy Kimmel hosted this, when Hollywood does what they did, 50 percent of the country said if I tune in I'm giving up on President Trump or President Bush or Republicans, and I will not give those Democrats ratings.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know what I find interesting, the goody bag, Kimberly, had over $100,000 in trips and electronics and do that, and it proves that point. The more that you get in life, the more you get in life. Like, these people do not need free things.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yeah. Billionaires don't pay for anything. But then, you know, everybody likes a little swag bag. And believe me, they're the first to grab them, OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah, yeah, they are. They'll trample over a poor family to get that trip.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Oh, and people try to take two and then not go through the line and give it to their driver and go back through again. That was the other Meryl Streep.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Put me in this one. It's bad.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That was Glenn Close.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: You don't want to be too negative on the Oscars. I'll give you some positives.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: I liked the whole thing with the jet ski.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Brilliant. The jet ski was brilliant. The idea you give the shortest speech, you win a jet ski and a trip to Lake Havasu.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Some casting director got it for 31 seconds.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That was hilarious.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Who wants to go to Lake Havasu? Kidding. I know my sister goes to Lake Havasu.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Wow. I guess we know where your bread is buttered.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, I know Lake Havasu.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: By the way, you know what -- you guys haven't mentioned?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I thought -- and this picks up on what you were talking about, the entertainment factor that people want to be entertained.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Often times, the best movies are not blockbuster hits is what I'm trying to say, and none of these are. They're good movies. But the ones that are blockbuster hits, right now, the ones -- guess what, you have women like Wonder Woman, right, a woman, and then you have.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Black Panther.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Black Panther, and even Get Out, a horror film with a black lead actor. I think there's something different given #metoo going on in Hollywood. So maybe they are changing, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I thought -- my favorite moment in the Oscars was Eva Marie Saint. She's 93. She's more articulate in coaching than anybody out there. And I think what's missing, it's like -- I liked to watch -- when I was a kid I like to watch the Oscars to see Charlton Heston and Jimmy Stewart. They come out and they're not their characters. They're themselves. But in this case, when you see movie stars now, they are -- they conform to a certain character about saying the right things, the right moral posture. That didn't exist in the '70s. They were just out there getting drunk.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: But you know what, that's -- I can't follow you. That's all right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I know.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: I was going to follow you but I can't pretend to. I will say this, why can't the biggest box office smash hit be lauded? Why can't they get awards?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You mean Trump, the movie?

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Trump is a bigger movie than all of them.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Like Black Panther is not get any awards. It's eligible for next year, right? It's not going to get any awards.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I bet it does.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It will get best picture nod, no question.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, I don't think so.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You don't think so?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It could be. But I don't think.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's the right movie.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: X-men? How many awards did X-men win?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: None.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Because they're the most successful movies don't get awarded. As if they're saying, I know what you like but I know better.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: My favorite Oscars story. Do we have a picture of Emma Watson? A lovely actress. I think, I hope that this is actually a temporary tattoo. It probably is. But it says times up, a salute to the movement. But there's no apostrophe. I think she should sue.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I wonder -- think it's a temporary tattoo.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Henna?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: A misspelled temporary tattoo. How lame.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: A damning assessment by Dana Perino. She's an expert on temporary henna tattoos, by the way.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You know if you're going to get a tattoo, make it temporary. I mean, really.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: What about the people disinvite? Casey Affleck can't go. James Franco can't go.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Do you have time when you have to wrap on Fox & Friends?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Not at all.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Usually people are screaming at me.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: New calls for a second special counsel. That's next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The DOJ has come under some scrutiny for how it obtained a FISA court warrant on a former member of the Trump campaign. Support is now growing among Republicans in congress for a second special counsel:

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: I expect the inspector general to issue a fact-centric fair report. I don't think the inspector general, himself, can answer all of our questions. Some of these witnesses have already left the department, which means the inspector general does not have jurisdiction. And there are other agencies like the state department where Michael Horowitz at DOJ has no jurisdiction whatsoever. So I think we're trending perhaps towards another special counsel, because of this unique fact pattern and the fact that there are witnesses outside the reach of the inspector general.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So Kimberly, this is a shift. For a long time, Republicans have been saying they believe that Michael Horowitz, the inspector general, could handle all of this. And there are mechanisms by which the inspector general, if he needed to, get a previous DOJ employee to talk to him. If they're not willing to, that he could use a U.S. attorney to go -- but I think what the Republicans are trying to do here is to try to stop the partisanship of this investigation and try to see if they should go to a second special counsel. The question for you is should they be careful what they wish for on that?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Well, certainly, right? I mean, it's kind of a double edge sword. When you think about it, you know, you say OK. Well, basically it sounds like a good idea. And you are seeing more of a measure of support from Republicans to do that. You saw a lot of that across the airwaves today, former tea party guy, Jordan saying it as well. But perhaps it would be warranted or this is an important situation. But yes, it is a shift in Republican paradigm to even say let's go to a special counsel. When you think about the amount of work and the things they have to do to get through it and try to do something expeditiously in the interest of efficiency, as well in getting away from partisan politics. It sounds like a good idea but it could also lead to a whole other road and take forever and give more time to go through things. One of the criticisms of Mueller is -- OK, how about focusing on what you originally were looking at in the original charges, the original focus and scope of the investigation, then it tends to always broaden out. Tentacles.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right. And then, Juan, I guess another problem could be that it depends on who you get as a special counsel, because then, if it's not -- if that person is not to President Trump's liking or the Democrats' liking, then maybe there still won't be any trust at the end of this. But there's two things, as I understand it, this would be for, supposedly, possible FISA (INAUDIBLE). But I think that a lot of people in the Trump world think this would be for everything including Hillary Clinton's emails.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, exactly. And in fact, a lot of this really stems from one so-called Republican, Donald Trump, because he's the one that's been going after the inspector general, Michael Horowitz, and saying, hey, that's an Obama guy. Why aren't you, Mr. Magoo, speaking to his attorney general in the most disrespectful way possible? Why aren't you getting Justice Department lawyers to work on this case instead of the inspector general? And then he says go after Hillary Clinton, but that's not what this is about. It's supposed to be about questions regarding FISA and, again, his own Justice Department. His own FBI says this is not -- this is reckless, this is dangerous, don't do it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, Brian, one possible thing is the inspector general, the Justice Department is having to investigate the Justice Department. And having worked there, I know that can't be done, but the possibility of having a second special counsel would then perhaps give this a veneer of credibility that the investigation right now doesn't have because of what's happened to the politicization of the intel committee.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Couple of things. The casual way of which Juan Williams said Mr. Magoo in the conversation, just go to show you.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: He didn't say it casually.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: I know. But just the way he says Mr. Magoo, of course, we know Jeff Sessions. I am as curious as anybody what Loretta Lynch did behind closed doors. I'm very curious what happened with James Comey. I am very curious what's going on with this FISA court. I do not -- as much as frustrated as everybody is, mostly Republicans are, but some Democrats, I don't want another special counsel. The country cannot go through this again. It makes everything fundamentally worse. It makes people go into their corners. We never get anything done. I echo what Condoleezza Rice said at the end of The View, when she looked over at Adam Schiff and she said I understand you have an important job but wrap it up. The country needs to get over this. If we go do this again and we start living 2015 and 2016, it will be bad for the country and it will not help the Republicans either.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, I mean, it could help the Republicans, I guess. Or maybe it would just be good to get justice.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I disagree with everything that Brian Kilmeade said.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: What is going on.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I believe that a second counsel -- special counsel is not enough. We need a third special counsel, and we need a fourth special counsel. It should never end. It should be special counsel roshambo, like I've said before. People are already in their corners. This is all team sports stuff. There's an ongoing mission going on right now. It's not to beat Trump, it's to stop Trump, because I think that the media and the Democrats have realized that they actually have to admit that President Trump is doing a much better job as president than they can admit or can actually fight. And it actually may end up -- has a lot more in common with the American public's perceptions than them. So what they have to do is stop him, not beat him. This is what they're doing.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Second special counsel would be, supposedly, to help President Trump.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah. You know what, I've tuned out. Like a said, special counsel.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: He's not better as they thought. He just doesn't go down with a punch. They thought they'd hit him a couple of times and he would go down.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Instead, it turns out he doesn't mind it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: That's what they say the chaos, he doesn't mind the chaos.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, he doesn't.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: We're going to talk about that because ahead, turmoil in the White House. The president's former chief of staff says don't be distracted by the talk. Next.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Chaos, turmoil, madness, no, not The Five. But all kinds of word are being thrown around to describe the Trump White House. Someone who once had a front seat to it all says ignore the talk. The president process may be different, but it's getting great results. Here's Reince Priebus.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: You can't look at the distractions. I think what the staff has to do is focus in on the results. And so, I think what the president does and he writes about it even in his own books, is he puts rivals around him intellectually. You have people like Wilbur Ross, who was going to be on your show, and Gary Cohn, and he puts those two guys in front of him and says, OK, fight out tariffs in front of me and they fight it out. The media covers the fight, but ultimately the decision is made. Look at the economy. Look at ISIS. Look at the courts. The decisions and the things that President Trump has done have put him on a great course. That process, while different, has gotten to good results. And that's what I think people need to do.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: OK. It's very curious to see Reince Priebus out, kind of doing these talking points on the Sunday show. So he's trying to direct the attention away from chaos, away from General Kelly, or staff changes, Cohn, McMaster, is there turmoil there to say, OK. Well, the process and make it about the president, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So Reince hasn't really done a lot of press from about.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: . August until recently. I assume that maybe he got the time off that he needed. And that the White House is looking for allies and support and ask him if he would consider going out there and talking about things from his perspective because he was there. He has credibility from that point. I would say from the chaos standpoint, it's never as bad as it looks from the outside because 98 percent of people who worked at the White House have very specific jobs that they have to do. The government is clearly running well and on time, so that's isn't a concern. Maybe it's 95 percent at this White House because there is no doubt that we talk about the personnel issues at this White House all the time, and a lot of that is self-imposed. But the crowdsourcing of the policy debate, it is different. Like we are having a debate about tariffs this week out in the open and we're all participating. I have people on my show today participating and everyone is sending in input, so it's a different way to do policy time, and it just ends up being what it is. I would say also though that when the President was able to work more cooperatively with Paul Ryan and Mitch McConnell in the Congress and that started around August-September, that's when a lot of these things started really coming together for getting a lot of accomplishments done. Things turned the corner, so that now, when you have a week where it looks like there's chaos, at least they can point back and say, "Well, it might be chaos, but at least, you should like the results. Don't you like the economy? And so, Ryan says something to go out and talk about.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes, it is. It's curious to see him kind of back out again, but it's highlighting the point that maybe things weren't going so well when he was there? Is it going better when Kelly is here, it's kind of -- it seems like he is helping to try to push some of the press away from General Kelly -- chaos -- Cohn, McMaster -- all of that, which I think is very specific that this isn't happening by accident, but as to the moral piece too, it's you know, good advice for the internal staff not to get distracted. If morale is super low, you do run the risk of losing good people.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: You do and a couple of things, I am not sure I believe a lot of it. Some of it is flat-out contradictory. According to four sources inside the White House, John Kelly has been used as a confidant by the President to get rid of Jared and his daughter. Really? I am having the marine four-star general run interference to tell Ivanka, "I need you to go home and work on shoes and dresses."

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: You really believe that?

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: No, I don't, but that's part of the headlines and part of the narratives. Some of this stuff is contradictory and does not make sense.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Okay.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: So, I don't buy that it is as chaotic as it is. Also, you have a guy in there who doesn't mind having unrest where you and I perhaps might have stomach churning moments, he is fine with it. Did you see him Friday at that -- when he was talking about tariffs? Didn't have a care in the world. You see and hear about him Saturday at the Gridiron, he had a great time, and the fund-raiser Friday night, the guy is not getting worked up.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, meaning President Trump?

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes. Well, he seems to be able to thrive or survive well in chaos or stability. Right? I mean, that's kind of his nature. He is used to it. Juan, what do you think?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I just don't understand. It seems to me total chaos. I mean, and I would just say look at the guns debate last week where one minute it looks like "Oh, he is taking on the NRA." Then the NRA comes back and says, "No, he agrees with us." No resolution. How about the trade debate? "Oh, one minute it says, yes, we are going to impose tariffs," And guess what? The stock market goes bananas, then he says, "You know, I am not so sure, but then yes, we are going to use it as a leverage point in terms of what's going on with Canada, our friend, and Mexico, our friend, in terms of the NAFTA debate." It's like, wait a second, White Houses -- Dana could speak to this -- typically are hierarchical and stick to message, so the message is clear to the public for political advantage. Here there is no -- it is like, you are a Republican? Like what side are the Republicans at? Today, Paul Ryan, the Speaker of the House, says, "I am not with Trump on trade." How is that helpful? What is the strategy? What is the strategy besides.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: . attacking your own Attorney General as Mr. Magoo, Brian?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Okay, well, who should be managing that, Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I am busy.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Captain Chaos?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Look, number one the -- we know why there is chaos. It's because we can see it, and I have said this before. This is the most transparent entity since Brian Stelter's hair. You can go see everything going inside of the White House, so that makes it look like there is more chaos. What I find interesting is how the media views Donald Trump as this incredibly divisive character when he has the most amorphous politics you could ever imagine. He is all over the place on immigration, guns, and trade. Guns, as you point out. Trade, as you point out, and even with immigration. He's going to let 1.7 million people in. It's because he's a populist and non-ideologue, which confuses people like us who play team sport politics, who believe that there is a right and left and set ideologies. He has more in common, and this may be bad, but it may be good, but he may have more in common with the average apolitical citizen who, when they hear an idea, they like that idea, but they also like that idea and both ideas might contradict each other. But he listens to both of them. To him and to the average, apolitical citizen, politics is a buffet and you walk in to that buffet and you can like this or here and you can like this over here, you don't see them as two separate teams. You say like, " I want the guns out of the hands of the crazy people. I want my guns." So, Trump goes, "You are both right." Because that is populism. So, it is what's popular and it changes because.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But it strikes me as like almost an autocrat.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes, that (inaudible) -- like this, an autocrat. Ahead, President Trump breaking bread with the press this weekend and he actually had a great time, like Brian said, Gridiron dinner highlights when "The Five" returns.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: President Trump put his feud with the media on ice this weekend and guess what? He said he's never had so much fun. Can you believe it? Mr. Trump was actually self-deprecating.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: There we go -- at the annual Gridiron dinner in a roomful of journalists. Too bad it wasn't televised. But we've got you some quotes. He joked about the turnover at the White House, the impeachment calls, and more. He began with a clever apology for being a little late because his son-in-law, Jared -- and here I am just about quoting, "Could not get through security." Jared was there along with the first daughter, Ivanka. He also poked fun at his embattled Attorney General, Jeff Sessions saying, "Here with us tonight, I offered him a ride over, and he recused himself." The President even surprisingly had nice words for the press, and this is an accurate quote, folks, "I do have a lot of respect for a lot of people in this room. I want to think that press for all you do to support and sustain our democracy. I mean that." So, Dana, he hasn't accepted the White House correspondents' dinner.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's okay.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: . this is the first time that he's done business with the press on a social level.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I heard his going.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, I haven't heard of it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I have no idea. I haven't been since 2008 and I don't plan to go again to the White House correspondents' dinner, but I love the Gridiron dinner. I think it's the best one, and one of the reasons it's the best is because it's not on camera. It is not televised. It has been going on for 160 years or something like that. It's at the Long Hill Club. It's one of the best nights in DC. I love the satire of it and I think that we all benefit from a night where the press and the President can hobnob behind the scenes, say whatever they want. Their motto is "The Gridiron singes, but it never burns." And I am a big fan of that night, but I don't care if he goes to the correspondents' dinner. Sorry, guys, I just don't, but I'm sorry.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Kimberly?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I like it. I like the Gridiron. I thought that was a good show. The president is in good humor. I think it was a nice juxtaposition to a lot of the press out there, the chaos and this matter of what's going on, you know, here domestically, also you know, internationally. So, to see him in kind of good humor, making that kind of like inroads with the media, I thought that was good. You know, it just shows his flexibility and his versatility. And then, he's very good at these events, and I don't know, I am hearing he is going to do the White House correspondents' dinner. I mean, I'd like to go.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, I am sure that you'll be invited.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Brian likes to go.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Brian like to go?

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
utterances.utterance: It's going to be great.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: He used to bailout on it.

utterances.speaker: KILMEADE
